thread.title: Come Over to the Dark (Beer) Side

author: William Bostwick
title: Come Over to the Dark (Beer) Side
text:
IF CRAFT BEER teaches us anything, itâ€™s that looks can be deceiving. Serious brews have the silliest names; corner dives offer rare brews on tap. And dark beers, presumed to be bearers of barrel-aged heft and boozy potency, now beguile with unexpected flavors. Dark can be tart, smooth, hoppy, fruited and even, yes, light.

Beer gets its color from grain; blacker brews start with roasted malts, dried over higher heat than the pale malts used in Pilsners and IPAs. Dark grains may be cooked hot and fast like coffee beans, toasted...
